text: Onboarding is the only part of your product experience that a hundred percent of people are ever going to touch. Good luck getting a hundred percent feature adoption of anything else in your product, right? But onboarding is the thing that you have to go through in order to use the product. It's also the first opportunity that you have as a company to deliver on the promise that you made out in the marketplace.
speaker: Adam Fishman
context: Lenny asks Adam about the importance of onboarding as a growth lever. Adam explains why onboarding deserves significant attention from product and growth teams. He emphasizes that unlike other features which may have low adoption rates, every single user must go through onboarding to use your product. He frames onboarding as the critical moment where companies can either deliver on their marketing promises or disappoint new users.
text_ko: 온보딩(onboarding)은 제품 경험에서 100%의 사용자가 꼭 거치게 되는 유일한 부분이에요. 제품의 다른 어떤 부분에서든 100%의 기능 채택(feature adoption)을 얻기란 거의 불가능하죠. 하지만 제품을 쓰려면 꼭 거쳐야 하는 게 온보딩이에요. 또 이는 회사가 시장에서 내세운 약속을 실제로 보여줄 수 있는 첫 번째 기회이기도 해요.
text_zh: 用户引导(onboarding)是你产品体验中唯一一个百分之百用户都会接触到的环节。你想让产品其他功能达到百分之百的使用率？基本不可能，对吧？但用户引导不一样，这是用户想用你产品就必须经历的过程。同时，这也是你们公司兑现市场承诺的第一次机会。
text_es: El onboarding es la única parte de la experiencia de tu producto que el cien por ciento de la gente va a usar sí o sí. A ver si logras que el cien por ciento de los usuarios adopte cualquier otra funcionalidad de tu producto, ¿no? Pero el onboarding es algo por lo que tienes que pasar obligatoriamente para poder usar el producto. También es la primera oportunidad que tienes como empresa para cumplir con la promesa que hiciste en el mercado.

text: I like to think of your brand is the promise that you're making and your product experience is your delivery of that promise. And those two things have to be in lockstep with each other, or you're going to have mismatched expectations and some really disappointed customers. So this is the first chance that a customer has to be really excited or really disappointed in what they thought they were getting. So don't mess that up.
speaker: Adam Fishman
context: Adam continues explaining why onboarding is such a crucial growth lever. He describes the relationship between marketing/branding and product experience, emphasizing that your brand creates expectations while your product must fulfill them. He warns that if these aren't aligned, you'll create disappointed customers. Adam stresses that onboarding is the first moment of truth where customers decide if the product matches what was promised.
text_ko: 저는 브랜드(brand)를 여러분이 하는 약속이라고 생각해요. 제품 경험(product experience)은 그 약속을 실제로 전달하는 방식이에요. 이 둘은 반드시 발을 맞춰야 해요. 그렇지 않으면 기대가 어긋나고 고객이 크게 실망하게 돼요. 고객이 자신이 받게 될 것에 대해 설레거나 실망하게 되는 첫 번째 기회가 바로 이 지점이에요. 그러니 이걸 망치지 마세요.
text_zh: 我觉得品牌就是你对客户的承诺，而产品体验就是你兑现这个承诺的过程。这两个必须完全同步，不然客户的期望就会落空，最后肯定会很失望。这是客户第一次真正体验你的产品，要么让他们特别惊喜，要么让他们特别失望。所以千万别搞砸了。
text_es: Me gusta pensar que tu marca es la promesa que estás haciendo y la experiencia del producto es cómo cumples esa promesa. Y estas dos cosas tienen que ir de la mano, si no, vas a tener expectativas que no coinciden y clientes súper decepcionados. Entonces esta es la primera oportunidad que tiene un cliente de emocionarse de verdad o llevarse una decepción tremenda con lo que pensaba que iba a recibir. Así que no la riegues.

text: One of the challenges of hiring a senior person is that they're all off writing newsletters and making podcast. Not that we know anybody who does that or anything, but... So I don't want to right now go back and work at a company again. I'm enjoying what I'm doing and so it's hard to get me, right? But also you don't want me, I think, when you're doing this for the first time.
speaker: Adam Fishman
context: Lenny asks Adam whether founders should focus on hiring up-and-coming growth people versus senior experienced leaders. Adam humorously points out that many senior growth practitioners (like himself and Lenny) have moved away from full-time roles to focus on content creation and consulting. He suggests that founders shouldn't necessarily want the most senior person anyway when building their first growth function.
vocabulary_highlights: when you're doing this for the first time
text_ko: 시니어를 채용할 때의 어려움 중 하나가 다들 뉴스레터(newsletter) 쓰고 팟캐스트(podcast) 만들고 있어서 구하기가 어렵다는 거예요. 딱히 누굴 지목하려는 건 아니지만요... 그래서 저도 지금 당장 회사로 다시 들어가고 싶진 않아요. 지금 하는 일이 재미있어서 저를 데려오기 쉽지 않고요. 게다가 이런 걸 처음 해보는 분들한테는 저 같은 사람을 원하지도 않을 거라고 생각해요.
text_zh: 招聘高级人才的一个难点就是，这些人现在都跑去写newsletter、做播客去了。不是说我们认识什么这样的人啊，但是吧...所以我现在也不想回去给公司打工了。我现在做的事情挺享受的，所以你很难挖到我，对吧？但是话说回来，如果你是第一次创业的话，其实你也不会想要我这样的人。
text_es: Uno de los problemas de contratar a alguien con experiencia es que todos andan haciendo sus newsletters y podcasts. No es que conozcamos a nadie que haga eso ni nada, pero... La cosa es que yo ahora mismo no tengo ganas de volver a trabajar en una empresa. Me gusta lo que estoy haciendo y entonces es difícil que me convenzan, ¿no? Pero además creo que tampoco me querrían cuando están empezando con esto por primera vez.

text: If you're going to hire a junior person, the key is, how do you help them learn? And I think if you don't know what you're doing as the founder or the leader, it's hard. You're not going to be able to help them yourself. So you've got to be willing to invest in advisors like me, outside education, mentorship, coaching, otherwise, what's going to happen is that very driven, hungry and enthusiastic person is going to run through a lot of brick walls, which is great, except they're going to miss the fact that the door was standing right next to the wall that they just ran through and you're going to end up with a lot of bricks on the ground.
speaker: Adam Fishman
context: Adam continues discussing the challenge of hiring junior growth people. He explains that if founders choose to hire someone less experienced, they must invest in that person's development through advisors, education, and mentorship. Without proper guidance, even the most motivated junior hire will make costly mistakes by trying to solve problems the hard way instead of finding easier solutions.
vocabulary_highlights: run through a lot of brick walls
the door was standing right next to the wall
end up with a lot of bricks on the ground
text_ko: 주니어(junior)를 채용할 거라면 핵심은 그 사람이 어떻게 배우도록 도와줄 거냐예요. 그리고 창업자(founder)나 리더(leader)로서 본인이 뭘 하고 있는지 모르면 그들을 직접 도와주기 힘들어요. 그래서 저 같은 어드바이저(advisor)나 외부 교육, 멘토링(mentorship), 코칭(coaching)에 기꺼이 투자할 준비가 돼 있어야 해요. 그렇지 않으면 의욕 넘치고 열정 있는 사람이 벽을 마구 부딪치며 달려가겠지만, 정작 그들이 부딪친 바로 옆에 문이 서 있었던 걸 못 보고 지나쳐 버려서 결국 바닥에 벽돌만 잔뜩 남게 될 거예요.
text_zh: 如果你要招一个新人，关键是你怎么帮他们成长。我觉得如果你作为创始人或者领导自己都不太清楚怎么做，那就很难办了。你没法亲自去指导他们。所以你得舍得投资，找像我这样的顾问，或者外部培训、导师指导(mentorship)、教练服务(coaching)什么的。要不然会怎么样呢？那些很有冲劲、很hungry、很有热情的人就会到处撞墙，这种拼劲当然是好事，但问题是他们撞墙的时候，往往没注意到墙边上就有门，结果地上一堆砖头瓦片的。
text_es: Si vas a contratar a alguien junior, lo clave es: ¿cómo lo vas a ayudar a aprender? Y creo que si tú como fundador o líder no tienes claro lo que haces, se complica mucho. No vas a poder ayudarlos tú mismo. Entonces tienes que estar dispuesto a invertir en asesores como yo, capacitación externa, mentores, coaching... porque si no, lo que va a pasar es que esa persona tan ambiciosa, con tantas ganas y entusiasmo, se va a estar dando cabezazos contra la pared todo el tiempo. Y está bien, el problema es que no se va a dar cuenta de que la puerta estaba justo al lado de la pared contra la que se estuvo golpeando, y al final vas a terminar con un montón de ladrillos en el suelo.

text: I actually think if you're doing it right, sometimes conversion should actually decrease a little bit. So you might actually have fewer people getting all the way through successfully, but I think that's okay because a lot of those people were probably not the right people for your product, which means they wouldn't have been engaged customers, they probably would have churned.
speaker: Adam Fishman
context: Lenny asks Adam how to think about the tradeoff between onboarding conversion and retention. Adam explains a counterintuitive insight about effective onboarding - sometimes it should actually convert fewer people overall. He argues that good onboarding acts as a filter, weeding out users who aren't a good fit for the product, which ultimately improves retention metrics even if conversion rates drop slightly.
text_ko: 사실 제대로 하고 있다면 전환율(conversion)이 오히려 조금 낮아질 때도 있어요. 그래서 최종까지 성공적으로 도달하는 사람이 줄어들 수 있는데, 그건 괜찮아요. 그런 사람들 대부분은 원래 우리 제품에 맞는 사람들이 아니었을 가능성이 크거든요. 활성 고객(engaged customers)이 되지 못하고 결국 이탈(churn)했을 거예요.
text_zh: 我觉得如果你做得对的话，转化率(conversion)有时候其实应该稍微降一点。可能真正走完整个流程的人会少一些，但我觉得这没关系，因为那些人本来就不是你产品的目标用户，也就是说他们不会是活跃用户，很可能最后还是会流失掉。
text_es: La verdad es que si lo estás haciendo bien, a veces la conversión debería bajar un poco. O sea, puede que tengas menos gente que complete todo el proceso exitosamente, pero creo que eso está bien porque muchos de esos probablemente no eran el cliente ideal para tu producto, lo que significa que no habrían sido usuarios comprometidos y seguramente se habrían dado de baja.

text: When you're interviewing at a company, you are actually investing an even more scarce resource. You're investing your time. There is no way to get more time. We're all on a finite clock. You can always get more money. If you make a bad investment decision, 'Okay, we lost there.' Provided you didn't bankrupt yourself. Even if you did, you can climb out of bankruptcy. There are things that you can do, but time is fleeting.
speaker: Adam Fishman
context: Adam is explaining his PMF framework for evaluating companies to work at (People, Mission, Financials). He draws an analogy between investment due diligence and job searching, arguing that candidates should be just as rigorous when choosing employers. He emphasizes that when you take a job, you're investing something more valuable than money - your time - which cannot be recovered if you make a poor choice.
text_ko: 회사에서 면접을 볼 때는 사실 훨씬 더 귀한 자원을 투자하는 거예요. 바로 시간이에요. 시간을 더 얻을 방법은 없어요. 우리 모두에게는 한정된 시간이 있어요. 돈은 언제든 더 벌 수 있죠. 투자 결정을 잘못해 손해를 봐도 ‘아, 거기서 졌구나’ 하고 넘길 수 있어요. 파산하지 않았다면요. 설사 파산을 했다 해도 다시 일어설 방법은 있어요. 하지만 시간은 금방 흘러가요.
text_zh: 面试的时候，其实你投入的是更稀缺的资源——时间。时间这个东西是没法增加的，我们每个人的时间都是有限的。钱可以再赚，投资失误了就失误了，"好吧，这次亏了"。只要没破产就行。就算真破产了，也能东山再起，总有办法。但时间不等人，过去就过去了。
text_es: Cuando estás en una entrevista de trabajo, en realidad estás invirtiendo un recurso aún más escaso. Estás invirtiendo tu tiempo. No hay manera de conseguir más tiempo. Todos tenemos el reloj corriendo en nuestra contra. Dinero siempre puedes conseguir más. Si tomas una mala decisión de inversión, "Bueno, ahí perdimos." Siempre y cuando no te hayas arruinado completamente. Y aunque así fuera, de la bancarrota se puede salir. Hay cosas que se pueden hacer, pero el tiempo se nos va volando.
